post: I'll admit. I was going to post whatever ChatGPT first gave me from what it ""knows"" about me. But then, for some unknown reason, sitting next to me was Ruth Bader Ginsburg. Why? I have no clue! üòÇ (See that image in the next frame) So what do we think of this end result?

1/ After their major house fire, my parents are finally settling into a rental. One of the most important things in a Jewish home is the mezuzah. Affixed to the right side of the doorway as you enter each room, it has a handwritten parchment that writes out our holy prayer of the Shema, within it.

If I told you this was a fun episode to watch, it would be an understatement. Watch these 13 pros as they laugh, love & discuss. First half is all about the world of poker. Second half are their thoughts on Israel and antisemitism. SO. GOOD! youtu.be/uVqjxzuIQdI @andybloch.bsky.social

Noooooooo! Thank you for the amazing memories. We will always miss: Kate McCallister Delia Deetz Cookie Fleck Moira Rose They were iconic characters, because YOU were iconic. @catherineohara.bsky.social

1/2 This is it. The final reel from this incredibly special episode about the Abraham Accords. I speak in it, and try to tie the conversation together. @atlanticcouncil.bsky.social @israelcc.bsky.social @jewishjournal.bsky.social

1/3 So get this. My parents house had its big fire recently. My parents haven't even moved into their temporary home yet, and my mother trips yesterday and spends the night in the ER looking like she's gone 10 rounds with Mike Tyson.

1/2 New ideas. Fresh blood. Thinking outside the box. Sometimes this is what's needed to actually make the impossible possible. What if some of the fractures in the Middle East could be improved with business deals? Filmmaker Zach Zorba brings a ""soft diplomacy"" perspective.

1/2 Former United States Ambassador Marc Sievers provided his expertise, both regarding how eye-opening the hatred against Israel is within universities, and also the need for the Abraham Accords to succeed. Really invaluable having him on, and he continues to do incredible work with the AJC.

1/2 Ksenia Svetlova wears many hats, as an Israeli politician, professor, and runs the organization ROPES. She explains that things with Saudi Arabia never seemed like they were as close as people thought, as they were always hinging normalization on stability with the Palestinians.

Nir Boms paints a fascinating backstory. In 2012 a powerful figure in the Muslim Brotherhood was given power. This was the final straw for more moderate Muslim countries, and helped them realize they needed what ultimately became the Abraham Accords. Fascinating! @telavivuni.bsky.social

1/2 Spotlighting the incredible Yaara Segal. This episode was her vision, born from her expertise on the Abraham Accords. It took months of dedication to bring together these voices of various faiths, and I couldn't be prouder of the result‚Äîor the friendship we‚Äôve built along the way.

8 nights of beautiful light. 8 nights of our wonderful & diverse community lighting the candles, & passing the torch to one another. I collaborated w my talented & lovely friend Eliana Jolkovsky in putting this together. Look who joined us! Be a light unto the nations. Be a light unto ourselves!

On the second night I read the names of each of the Jewish Australian terror victims. On the third night, I climbed the ladder and lit the candles, while still needing to answer the phone for my patients. @providencehealth.bsky.social

Chama Mechtaly was an amazing speaker and guest on my episode about the Abraham Accords. She explains the incredibly important context for the motivations behind more moderate Arab and Muslim countries, who want to normalize relations with Israel. @ahmedquraishi.bsky.social @ahmedkhuzaie.bsky.social

1/2 Knowing the context and history of the region is damn important. @ahmedquraishi.bsky.social explains it well, and has been a tremendous addition to the episode. He was interesting and delightful to have as a guest, and has supportively been in touch ever since. A real ally and friend.

The @atlanticcouncil.bsky.social is doing some amazing work, and when I contacted them about doing this episode on the Abraham Accords, they introduced me to Alex Plitsas, who's been truly awesome. Just a tremendously intelligent analysis on the complexities of the Middle East!

This will possibly be the most challenging episode I have ever done. But unbelievably worthwhile. We will have the honor to speak with a whopping 14 Holocaust Survivors, as well as 4 incredible people who help keep the stories alive. @simonwiesenthal.bsky.social @museumoftolerance.bsky.social

1/2 Amjad Taha was incredibly memorable. He was RUNNING to a CNN interview, and then going to meet President Trump. But he STILL honored us with his time, before needing to run. He's extremely positive and optimistic about how successfully the Abraham Accords have worked out.

1/2 This. This is what we need more of from the next generation of Academics. Students who actually learn about the Abraham Accords and coexistence, and bring dialogue back to their campuses. Not empty, vacuous virtue signaling protests. Thank you Ethan Winterstein for joining us!
1/3 Abdullah Antepli helped foster a truly interesting and nuanced dialogue about the Abraham Accords.

Dan Feferman has spent years of his adult life doing what I aspire to do. He builds bridges and fosters healthy and constructive dialogue between people who might not otherwise ever get a chance to meet and speak.

To kick off the individual reels spotlighting the wonderful guests on my Abraham Accords episode, here is @ahmedkhuzaie.bsky.social, who was lovely to correspond with from Day One. Full episode well worth watching, linked here: youtu.be/nOjZW_HfBo8?... @jewishjournal.bsky.social

1/2 The Abraham Accords. They were signed in 2020. What happens next? I gathered 14 experts (Jewish, Muslim, Christian) to discuss what was, what is, and what might happen to further peace or normalization in the Mideast: Follow me/the show on YouTube! youtu.be/nOjZW_HfBo8?...

1/2 I believe the hard conversations are what most NEED to be given a voice. This will be one of them. There are people out there, more than you know, whose spouses refuse to give them a (religious) divorce. This takes the already difficult scenario of divorce & makes it exponentially more awful.

1/2 To finish off my episode about Resilience, I drew in from my years of nursing experience, where we can't allow our empathy for our patients to affect us. I really appreciated being able to host this fascinating and important conversation!

Howard Rosenman has lived quite the life. Produced hit movies including Father of the Bride, but in our topic of Resilience, he tells us about the resilience he needed growing up gay in a tough, unforgiving world.
He's a world renowned Historian, and the way he speaks is just truly inspiring. Gil Troy really is awesome. And watch the full episode here: youtu.be/Mpbhv7Tw6h8

The idea of having a comedian on an episode about PTSD and resilience might seem insane, but it's exactly what the doctor ordered, as Tehran Von Ghasri added insight, empathy, and some much needed comic relief to the experience. Thank you my friend!
1/ Way back in 2009. I created my first cleanup of LA's Pico/Robertson neighborhood. There were a hundred of us, from Camp Boaz (yes that was a thing)!
A young musician tells us his harrowing story of October 7th survival. Thank you for opening up, Or Meir Ooliel. Full episode on my YouTube.

1/2 It was a true honor, a kavod, to have the venerable Rabbi YY Jacobson on my show about PTSD. He brought up the millennia of Jewish trauma, and explains how it has created a sense of self-loathing in many of us. Truly fascinating stuff.

One of the most underreported things about Israel, is how much national pride there is for many of its Israeli Arab citizenry. Maayan Hoffman is one of countless Jewish Israelis to have close friendships across the religious divide. @jewishjournal.bsky.social
1/ It's incredibly cool that they can visualize the brain and see some of the PTSD in real time.

This will not be exploitative. I will not be showing graphic videos. It is entirely to honor the memories of the many who were tragically lost that day, and serve as a giant hug for those left behind. #neverforget #September11 @fdny.bsky.social @nypd.bsky.social @september11.bsky.social

Barbara Heller does such a GREAT job of vocalizing how after decades of intifadas, Israelis really need to talk, scream and listen. A friend for so many years, Barb is going to be such a natural fit adding Marriage and Family Therapy to her large toolbox!

My incredible sisters-in-law Rikki and Karin created Orot Healing, focusing their efforts on PTSD. First for the Nova Survivors who they brought to a retreat a year and a half ago, and now for the soldiers that the show Fauda is based on, as well as their spouses.

10 second favor I'm going to ask of you on Bluesky. Follow me on YouTube. Everyone and their mother keeps telling me I should monetize my show. I don't know if I ever will, but I do know that I need 1,000 subscribers to even potentially monetize. www.youtube.com/@boazhepner

1/2 This is gonna be fun! For years I've watched shows like Survivor and Traitors, And one of my favorite parts is getting to watch the reunion episode when they gather much of the cast, and find out what's happened since then. Now I get to do it myself, for Netflix's ""Jewish Matchmaking!""
He's a talented musician. His words are frequently published in the @jewishjournal.bsky.social. And it was a pleasure having Peter Himmelman on the show!

1/ If I was Muslim, I can't even pretend to guess how I would feel about Israel, Jews, Antisemitism, as well as Islamism. What I do know, is that Soraya Deen is a proud Muslim woman, who stands up in the face of hatred from so many, so that she can be a true ally to Jewish and Israeli men and women.

1/2 She lives in Israel. She helps others with their trauma, as a therapist. But she has trauma herself, because everyone does in Israel. Fascinatingly, Micki Lavin-Pell explained how therapeutic it's been for so many in Israel to step up and help each other through their shared traumas. Beautiful.

This is insane. On my Instagram feed, hundreds of thousands of people every day continue to debate whether putting Liam on the ride was irresponsible. This is so funny. Look at those numbers at the bottom, WTF üòÇ

1/2 Chava Floryn is inspiring. Just a couple of months after the horror show that was October 7th, she was flying to Israel to film her latest documentary. ""Resilient"" explores how both individuals and an entire nation try to cope with PTSD on both the micro and macro scale.

1/3 I'm excited about every episode I create - why else would I do this (for free!) - but this time I get to talk to some of the greatest poker players in the world, including the guy who literally just won the WSOP Main Event? This is going to be SO. DAMN. FUN.

Apparently putting Little Liam on a Sesame Street ride for all ages stirs controversy. Over 2.5 MILLION views and counting! I get really offensive comments on my show that's frequently pro-Israel themes, so a few hundred ‚Äòchild abuse‚Äô comments from rabid parenting trolls? Those legit made me laugh.

1/5 Time to spill a secret. While I was sleeping at UCLA Hospital with Adi for 13 long nights, getting Natalia her diagnosis and treatment for PANS, I was keeping myself sane by pouring myself into my advocacy.
Liam generally has a ""resting pout face,"" but damn if it isn't adorable when he lets that smile shine.

1/2 On 1/3/24, my old friend told me the shocking thing he found on Arabic Wikipedia pages. I helped get a few articles published about it. 18 months later, I'm proud to have created the episode on the topic of Wikipedia. Fittingly, my final reel is me telling the story, and summing things up.

1/2 When someone diminishes the magnitude of the Holocaust, they are called a Holocaust Denier. When someone keeps diminishing the magnitude of The Protocols of the Elders of Zion, they are simply called @wikipedia.org
1/2 It was a pleasure to have Yfat Barak Cheney and her esteemed @worldjewishcong.bsky.social represent on the episode about @wikipedia.org!

1/2 I knew we‚Äôd speak to investigative journalists about Wikipedia‚Äôs bias ‚Äî but having Jonathan M. Weiss, a veteran Wikipedia editor, give us his insight? Next level. @jewishjournal.bsky.social @worldjewishcong.bsky.social @standwithus.bsky.social

1/2 This is the second time I've had Jordan Cope on my show, because he speaks so darn well. This time, he explains what he's seeing regarding Wikipedia's lack of neutrality. @standwithus.bsky.social is lucky to have him, and so were we.

1/2 Even when they have their Visas revoked, or their management drops them; even if they lose endorsements, it will keep happening. People will say awful things about Israel, Zionists, or just straight up Jews. It has happened in ebbs and flows over the millennia. It's certainly happening right now

1/2 In today's incessantly dramatic news cycle, it's hard to time things to avoid the headlines. But when everyone I know in Israel was hiding in their bomb shelters 3 times a day, plus Shanna Fuld whose home was actually blown up...I sure as heck waited.
Umm.... Houston, we have a problem... I can't stop laughing in horror at this joke that somehow made its way into my 7 year old daughter's joke book that she bores us with every day. WTF... üò± üòÇ

This week I had the honor of sharing a meal with @asranomani.bsky.social. When I finally get to meet the esteemed Judea Pearl, father of Jewish victim of terror, journalist Daniel Pearl, it will bring my crazy story full circle. Published in the @jewishjournal.bsky.social, VERY worth reading.

What a fun night that was! I had the pleasure to meet up with my longtime pen-pal @asranomani.bsky.social in her neck of the woods, and the long overdue meeting was wonderful. This Jewish man and that Muslim woman are fighting for a better future for all of us. See you soon my friend. ‚ù§Ô∏è

1/2 It's high time that people realize just how negligently biased Wikipedia has become. A leader in this information war, is Wikipedia Researcher Dr. Shlomit Aharoni Lir, who I had the honor to have on my show.

I always feel a bit strange going to work at the hospital on Shabbat. As Walter says to Lebowski, ""I don't roll on Shabbos."" But I'm a nurse, and people's health comes first. And today it all came together in a beautifully tragic way.
1/2 David Wiseman thinks that the more errors Wikipedia is proven to make, the sooner the general public will stop trusting it for their facts. @jewishjournal.bsky.social @worldjewishcong.bsky.social

There are lousy things that happen to us, like last week when antisemites screamed at me from their car for a third time since October 7th. Then there are times when I appreciate humanity for what it can be. Like today.

1/2 Is @wikipedia.org merely reflecting what the world media already thinks of us? When they falsely present information about Israel, are they making things up, or are they merely a reflection of the false narrative told by much of the press? David Swindle lends his expertise.

1/2 Christian Gribneau. I‚Äôll always be grateful that you took the time to be on the show, but heartbroken that you‚Äôre not here to see the impact you made. Thank you for your expertise, and kindness. You were an ally to all people seeking truth and transparency everywhere.
Today. This happened to me. And my young kids who thankfully didn't notice. Sick of being a target, but yet gaslit into being told I'm not.

1/3 A blood libel. How tragically accurate that allegation turned out to be! Misinformation and disinformation create ignorance at best, and can even lead to radicalized violence, such as the horrific ""Free Palestine"" screaming murderer in DC just yesterday.

1/2 This is huge. When I finished filming my Wikipedia episode, my dearly departed guest Christian Gribneau made intros to a higher up at RealClearPolitics and RealClearInvestigations, who wanted to start their own investigation into the so-called neutral company.

1/2 Ever wonder just how reliable your @wikipedia.org search results are? We think of the site as nothing more than a neutral, digital encyclopedia, but what happens when we pull back the curtain? Join me, as I spoke to 11 experts about Wiki's Israel problem: youtu.be/UZR8oSNHsDA

Sweet! Thank you SO much Voyagela for profiling me in this wonderful article. It really tells my story about me and my advocacy efforts beautifully. Hat tip to Sigal Erez for recommending me! @jewishjournal.bsky.social voyagela.com/interview/ri...

I am proud and honored to be gathering these prestigious individuals, and discuss the past, present and future of the Abraham Accords. If you have any questions you wish to ask the group, please send them to me directly or put them in the comments by the end of the day tomorrow May 13th.

Chosen Links did something special and new. This AAPI and Jewish Heritage Month, Eliana Jolkovsky shares with me and Nate Looney what brings her back to what matters: an act of solidarity in Korea that reminds us that humanity and empathy can still cross borders.

1/2 Why are we even having this conversation about the diversity of Jews? At the end of this wonderful episode, Nate Looney and I summed up our thoughts. I've been strongly advised that the reels I'm creating are great, but that the one person that nobody sees is the host, yours truly. So here! ‚ù§Ô∏è

1/2 @ElianaJolkovsky is awesome. She goes to med school at my alma mater @UCLA, and she's the first guest I've ever had who actually loved creating reels so much that she offered to create this one, and came up with the witty captions. Made me and Nate Looney's lives so much easier! :)

1/2 I love this. Why shouldn't our heritage matter? For someone who is fortunate enough to have adoptive parents, who's to say that the adoptive and biological heritage aren't each important to the person's identity.

Yesterday, as fires continued to rage in Israel, we celebrated Yom HaAtzmaut, Israel's version of July 4th. This reminds me of one year ago, when I wrote about my dear brother-in-law Adam finishing his Reserve duty, spending 2 weeks in LA, and flying back to Israel. @jewishjournal.bsky.social

1/2 Raymond Roker identifies as a really cool mix of Bahamian-American and Ashkenazi. He spent most of the episode synthesizing what everyone else was saying, and then expressed his appreciation for everyone else for having the courage to educate. I thank him for his own willingness to do the same!

This. Made. My. Day. On Shabbat someone in my synagogue saw Liam, and said that he looks like a baby @markhamillofficial.bsky.social. An hour later I had a dozen people approaching me that heard he's Baby Luke Skywalker, and now they can't unsee it! So he's Luke & Natalia's Nick Nolte's mugshot!

1/2 Such a likeable and eclectic guy! Bourn Rich is a talented artist who made me laugh, because after filming the episode, he apologized that he was enjoying listening to everyone else so much that he didn't speak enough. I LOVE knowing that this is a fun show to be a part of, it makes my day!

Only a lunatic would dare write a funny piece about the Holocaust, but I'm that lunatic, and this is my family's crazy story of how they survived the Nazis. Written by me, and published in the @jewishjournal.bsky.social a few years ago.

1/2 With all of the craziness with me lately I forgot to post this reel I created with Lani Mekeel, which has gone viral on Instagram. Watch her discuss how the image of her shifted, when she loudly revealed her Judaism.

1/2 One of my favorite moments I've experienced throughout my Chosen Links experience was right after this episode finished recording. Aimee actually texted me, ""Words don't describe how meaningful that evening was.""

1/2 Amy Albertson is refreshingly honest. Whether telling us her previous misconceptions about the Jewish community, or telling truths to people who don't want to hear it. She's a voice of clarity. And oh yeah, she's a proud Ashkenazi Jewish woman. @matthewnouriel.bsky.social

Iola emphasizes how our story comes from trauma and resilience. Fittingly, in 24 hours I'll be filming my next episode on that very topic! Do yourself a favor and watch the episode in full, for best effect: youtu.be/a8BUIfmya9w @matthewnouriel.bsky.social

1/2 There's so damn much to unpack in these 2 short minutes, about the vernacular ""Jew of color,"" about young Iranian activists in Iran... You should watch this. And rest assured, I plan to have @matthewnouriel.bsky.social again to talk about Iran!
#Jewsky repost to see if this helps

Abraham Hamra does not feel the need to say the right thing just to placate people. He's loud, he's proud, and he's totally worth watching. Can't wait for more episodes with him! Full episode with Abraham and everyone: youtu.be/a8BUIfmya9w @matthewnouriel.bsky.social

1/2 When I asked Jenny Cohen if she would be on my episode with other ""Jews of Color,"" she was genuinely conflicted. Yes she has always seen herself that way, as a Mexican Jew in America, but as her skin is white, she often gets dismissed when the topic arises, both from outsiders and from within.

1/2 Episode 11 is here! This one was fun, insightful, and full of diverse perspectives. I sat down with 14 Jewish men and women from different racial and ethnic backgrounds‚Äîalong with Nate Looney‚Äîto talk about their lived experiences. The resulting conversation was epic. youtu.be/a8BUIfmya9w

1/2 This is a cool and fun honor. I've been asked by Congregation Or Ami to be a guest speaker at their Affinity event, and discuss my efforts with gathering varieties of people on my show. It will be on Thursday, March 27th at 7pm on Zoom.

1/2 I must thank my co-moderator Nate for this introduction, because @aprilpowerstv.bsky.social adds important nuance to our conversation. Her professional and personal experiences make her how I want to finish off this wonderful episode where I was able to have this conversation with Black Jews.

My friend Rachel Moon has given me the pleasure of her company as a guest on 2 different episodes! She really impresses me with her capability to brush off the haters. People say racist things to her, they say antisemitic things to her, and she does NOT let it bother her. What's the secret sauce?
1/2 You want to hear a POWERFUL VOICE? Every word I've heard from @eli7chicnsweet.bsky.social during and since this episode, comes from a place of passion, something many of us are lacking.

I had a phenomenal conversation with these seven Black Jews and my co-moderator Nate Looney. First question was actually, do you even LIKE that label in the first place, and unsurprisingly, their answers were varied. youtu.be/yeQj5hokdz0 @aprilpowerstv.bsky.social @eli7chicnsweet.bsky.social

1/2 Please DM me any questions you have for this next episode I'll be filming in a week. We are doing a deep dive into the bias @wikipedia.org has been blatantly showing against Israel and so many things.

Please DON'T turn this into a pity party for me. I'll be fine. It's those who have suffered these great losses who I write this for. Send them letters and care packages and money. Check up on them, not me. Thank you.

1/3 So apparently what happened to me on Shabbat is technically called a ""hate incident,"" not to be confused with a ""hate crime."" I have literally no idea if Waymo is going to do a thing about it, but I reported it to them immediately after Shabbat. And we all know they have cameras up the wazoo.

1/2 This happened to me today. While the city I love is in flames, and people I know have lost their homes or are evacuated unsure if there will be a home to return to. It's supposed to be my ""Day of Rest,"" but instead I was full of anxious energy for the next few hours.

1/5 Are we okay? How to answer that. I'm in Santa Monica at Saint John's today, a hell of a first day back after helping Adi at home for 2 months with her broken back, and it's just depressing finding out how many people have lost their homes here.

1/ David Bowie sang, ""We can be heroes, just for one day."" But imagine being a hero every day. For an act that costs you no money, and just a little time. Organ donation. It's something we don't think about enough, but why? youtu.be/r2n5qLVz0rM

These posters make me really smile. Knowing I'm going to get to spend a few hours talking to each of these fascinating people with Nate Looney, as always going through the serious topics that need to be discussed, but always having some laughs. It's epic.

This app won't let me post anything over 60 seconds. That's way too limiting. So unless the rules change I'll just be sharing the full episodes and posters here, and none of the reels I create (such as the screenshot of my Instagram). Frustrating. Watch the full episode here: youtu.be/nJf2nwg3390

The next episode I'm lucky enough to record will be my second one with my trusted friend Nate Looney talking to these amazing Black Jews about their experiences as such - both positive and negative. Please send me your questions by Thanksgiving! And remember it's released a month or so later!

Guess I won't be able to post my reels here after all, because there's a 60 second limit. So ixnay on that whole idea to test out. But I'll still at least post my episodes. My latest being this wonderful and important conversation about the Black and Jewish communities. youtu.be/nJf2nwg3390

1/ I was about to post a reel from my latest episode of ""Chosen Links by Boaz"" when it hit me‚Äîthis is my first post on an app I‚Äôve never used before! So instead of diving right in, I figured I should start by introducing myself. Hi, Bluesky!
